item.title: Trump Threatens ‘Fire and Fury’ Against North Korea if It Endangers U.S.
item.media:description: Workers loading seafood in Rajin, North Korea, in 2013. The new sanctions ban United Nations member countries from importing seafood from the North, as part of penalties aimed at impeding its ability to pay for its weapons programs.
item.description: North Korea hinted that it would conduct another nuclear or missile test, as it has often done in response to past United Nations sanctions.
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER and CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Trump Threatens North Korea With ‘Fire and Fury’
item.description: “North Korea best not make any more threats to the United States,” President Trump said after the isolated nuclear-armed country criticized the United States earlier in the day.

item.title: Trump’s Harsh Language on North Korea Has Little Precedent, Experts Say
item.description: The statement went far beyond the usual tough-but-vague words that past presidents have used to confront the North’s frequent provocations.
item.dc:creator: JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS

item.title: Right and Left React to the Tensions With North Korea
item.media:description: An image released by the North Korean government was said to show a missile launch last month.
item.description: Read about how the other side thinks: Writers from across the political spectrum examine the growing tensions with North Korea.
item.dc:creator: ANNA DUBENKO
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament

item.title: North Korea’s Alarmed Neighbors Consider Deploying Deadlier Weapons
item.media:description: Japanese tanks during a 2016 exercise in Gotemba, southwest of Tokyo. Japan’s government said on Tuesday that North Korea may have already acquired nuclear warheads.
item.description: In Japan and South Korea, politicians are calling for new military capabilities, in what could become a regional arms race.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN SOBLE and CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Climate Report Could Force Trump to Choose Between Science and His Base
item.media:description: President Trump at a meeting on Tuesday at the Trump National Golf Club in Bedminster, N.J.
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.description: The looming publication of a climate report again raises a contentious policy issue that has deeply divided President Trump’s closest advisers since he arrived in the Oval Office.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL D. SHEAR and BRAD PLUMER
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change

item.title: North Korea, Jacob Zuma, Glen Campbell: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: KAREN ZRAICK and SANDRA STEVENSON

item.title: Europe Edition: North Korea, Brigitte Macron, Kenya: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.media:credit: Carl De Souza/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK BOEHLER

item.title: California Today: California Today: The Dominating Dodgers
item.media:description: Yu Darvish, among the most talented pitchers in baseball, is the latest star to join the Dodgers.
item.description: Tuesday: The Dodgers look unstoppable, a stormy semester at Claremont Colleges, and grappling over California’s right-to-die law.
item.dc:creator: MIKE McPHATE

item.title: The Culture Wars Have Come to Silicon Valley
item.media:description: Peter Thiel, left, and Reed Hastings. Mr. Thiel, a member of Facebook’s board of directors, was told by Mr. Hastings, the chief executive of Netflix, that he would receive a negative evaluation of his performance on the board because of his support for Donald J. Trump.
item.media:credit: Photo Illustration by Andy Chen/The New York Times. Photos by Andrew White for The New York Times; Justin Sullivan, via Getty Images
item.description: After Google fired an engineer who wrote an anti-diversity manifesto, the tech industry is under the microscope for penalizing dissenting opinions.
item.dc:creator: NICK WINGFIELD

item.title: Contentious Memo Strikes Nerve Inside Google and Out
item.media:description: Google has faced many questions about the number of women employed there as engineers and managers.
item.description: The memo, written by a Google engineer who was later fired, enraged diversity advocates and also served as a rallying cry for conservatives and the alt-right.
item.dc:creator: DAISUKE WAKABAYASHI

item.title: As Investigations Intensify, Israel Imagines Life After Netanyahu
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu arriving at a cabinet meeting last month. Mr. Netanyahu has dominated the Israeli political scene for years.
item.description: As an ex-aide turns state’s witness, Israelis across the spectrum are trying on the idea of the curtain coming down on Mr. Netanyahu’s career.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Trump Rewards Loyalty in Alabama Senate Race by Tweeting Endorsement
item.media:description: Senator Luther Strange, Republican of Alabama, last week in Washington.
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.description: The president threw his support to Senator Luther Strange in a special Alabama election in which Republicans have fought to appear the closest to Mr. Trump.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN MARTIN

item.title: Punch With Pakistani Girls at a Karachi Boxing Club
item.description: Boxing as a competitive sport for women has become increasingly popular in Pakistan in recent years. Put on your gloves and go a round in 360.

item.title: Your Daily Mini Crossword
item.description: Solve a bite-size crossword in just a few minutes.

item.title: Glen Campbell, Whose Hit Songs Bridged Country and Pop, Dies at 81
item.media:description: Glen Campbell playing guitar as host of the NBC television show “The Midnight Special” in 1975.
item.description: A sharecropper’s son who became a recording, television and movie star, Mr. Campbell also battled alcohol and drugs and became a public face of Alzheimer’s disease.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL POLLAK
item.category: By the Time I Get to Phoenix (Song)

item.title: Gun Rights and Foster Care Restrictions Collide in Michigan
item.media:description: Bill Johnson with his holstered handgun. He and his wife, Jill, are suing Michigan, which would bar them from carrying concealed weapons if they became their grandson’s foster parents.
item.media:credit: Tim Gruber for The New York Times
item.description: A couple have challenged a state law that bars foster parents from carrying concealed weapons in a case that may have nationwide implications.
item.dc:creator: SHERYL GAY STOLBERG

item.title: Economic Scene: The Danger From Low-Skilled Immigrants: Not Having Them
item.media:description: Thousands of Mexican workers cross the border legally each night from Mexico into California, where they pick up work as agricultural day laborers in California’s Imperial Valley.
item.description: A wealth of research shows that the economy is lifted by foreign workers, providing new opportunities for the native-born.
item.dc:creator: EDUARDO PORTER

item.title: Bill Murray Relives a Role, Seeing Broadway’s ‘Groundhog Day’
item.media:description: Bill Murray at the bar on Tuesday night at “Groundhog Day,” the Broadway musical based on the film in which he starred. He was attending the show for the first time.
item.media:credit: Hilary Swift for The New York Times
item.description: Mr. Murray attended the musical for the first time on Tuesday night, and the performance brought him to tears.
item.dc:creator: SOPAN DEB

item.title: Missouri Man Arrested in Fatal Shooting of Police Officer
item.media:description: Ian McCarthy, 39, the man suspected of killing a Missouri State Highway Patrol officer in Clinton, Mo., on Sunday night.
item.media:credit: Missouri State Highway Patrol, via Associated Press
item.description: The suspect, Ian McCarthy, was taken into custody on Tuesday night after the authorities received a call about a man walking down a rural road in Urich, Mo.
item.dc:creator: MATTHEW HAAG

item.title: Mike Duggan and Coleman Young Will Face Off in Detroit’s Mayoral Election
item.media:description: Coleman A. Young II campaigning last month at Clique, a local diner in Detroit, for the coming mayoral race. Mr. Young, 34, a state senator, is the son of Detroit’s first black mayor.
item.media:credit: Brittany Greeson for The New York Times
item.description: Mr. Duggan, the incumbent mayor, was far ahead among eight candidates, and Mr. Young, the son of Detroit’s longest serving mayor, was a distant second.
item.dc:creator: MONICA DAVEY

item.title: Kenyan Presidential Election Is Peaceful; Violence Feared Over Results
item.media:description: Lines at a polling station on Tuesday in Kibera, Kenya’s biggest slum.
item.description: There were few technical glitches compared to the previous election, in 2013, when many voting machines malfunctioned.
item.dc:creator: KIMIKO de FREYTAS-TAMURA

item.title: Jacob Zuma Beats Back No-Confidence Vote in South Africa
item.media:description: Opposition members in Cape town marched to support a no-confidence motion against President Jacob Zuma of South Africa on Tuesday.
item.description: The motion failed, with 177 yes votes and 198 no votes. Mr. Zuma has faced strong corruption allegations.
item.dc:creator: KIMON de GREEF and SEWELL CHAN

item.title: Northwestern Professor Held in Stabbing Death That Mystified Chicago
item.media:description: Wyndham Lathem, an associate professor at Northwestern University, was arrested on Friday in California.
item.media:credit: Alameda County Sheriff's Office, via Associated Press
item.description: Wyndham Lathem and another man were arrested in the killing of Trenton Cornell-Duranleau, a hairstylist, after a far-reaching manhunt.
item.dc:creator: MATTHEW HAAG

item.title: Impossible Burger’s ‘Secret Sauce’ Highlights Challenges of Food Tech
item.media:description: An Impossible Burger, which resembles meat but is made of plant products.
item.media:credit: Jason Henry for The New York Times
item.description: The start-up is finding out what happens when a fast-moving venture capital business runs into the staid world of government regulation.
item.dc:creator: STEPHANIE STROM

item.title: Sports of The Times: Justin Gatlin Is an Athlete of His Time, Not a Villain
item.media:description: Justin Gatlin, center, stood with the silver medalist Christian Coleman, left, and the bronze medalist Usain Bolt at a medal ceremony at the world championships on Sunday in London.
item.description: Fans showered Gatlin with boos after he ruined Usain Bolt’s farewell race, but the outrage edges toward the absurd.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL POWELL

item.title: Base Instinct: The Political Payoff of Making Whites Feel Like a Minority
item.media:description: A senior White House adviser, Stephen Miller, said that the Statue of Liberty is a “symbol of American liberty lighting the world” but that it had little to do with immigrants.
item.description: Survey data suggest that white Trump voters tend to feel a sense of threat about being discriminated against.
item.dc:creator: LYNN VAVRECK

item.title: Australian Leaders Plan Vote on Same-Sex Marriage, One Way or Another
item.media:description: A march in support of same-sex marriage in Sydney this week. Polls show that the majority of Australians believe same-sex marriage should be legalized.
item.description: Liberal Party officials say that if the Senate doesn’t open the polls for a nationwide vote on same-sex marriage, Australians will cast advisory ballots by mail.
item.dc:creator: JACQUELINE WILLIAMS and DAMIEN CAVE
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships

item.title: An Extreme 5,700-Mile Bike Race Across Russia Struggles to Keep Women in the Pack
item.media:description: From left, Peter Sandholt of Denmark, Marcelo Soares of Brazil and Pierre Bischoff of Austria during the 11th stage of the Red Bull Trans-Siberian Extreme race.
item.description: Organizers of the Trans-Siberian Extreme race are trying to make the event more attractive to women, after the two riding this year dropped out early.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTINE HAUSER

item.title: As Appetite for Soccer in U.S. Grows, So Does M.L.S.
item.media:description: M.L.S. Commissioner Don Garber was greeted by cardboard cutouts of himself last year when he visited Sacramento, one of a dozen cities vying for an expansion team in the league.
item.description: The league, which will add a new team in Los Angeles next year and is close to approving another in Miami, is vetting a dozen other cities for a planned expansion.
item.dc:creator: KEN BELSON

item.title: Free Alaskan Salmon: Just Bring a Net and Expect a Crowd
item.description: Amateurs pack the shores of the Kenai River, perhaps the most colorful, and contentious, fishing spot in America.
item.dc:creator: JULIA O'MALLEY

item.title: David Letterman Will Return to TV in a New Netflix Series
item.media:description: David Letterman
item.description: Mr. Letterman, the innovative late-night host, is preparing a program that will feature long-form interviews and his explorations of the wider world.
item.dc:creator: DAVE ITZKOFF

item.title: A Word With: 13 Shows. No Repeats. Trey Anastasio on How Phish Pulled Off the ‘Baker’s Dozen.’
item.media:description: Trey Anastasio of Phish said the band prepared for its 13-night residency, but in the end the shows were “a blur.”
item.media:credit: Chad Batka for The New York Times
item.description: The guitarist and singer explains how the band prepped for its longest residency, picked out its covers — and then ditched all of its plans.
item.dc:creator: JESSE JARNOW

item.title: 4,000 Kilometers, 10 Months: One Australian’s March for Indigenous Rights
item.media:description: Clinton Pryor on the Princes Highway near the town of Ulladulla last week. He said he started the trek partly to raise awareness about the forced closing of remote Aboriginal communities by the government.
item.media:credit: Brook Mitchell for The New York Times
item.description: Clinton Pryor is walking across the country to protest the treatment of Indigenous Australians, but the government has yet to heed calls for greater inclusion of Australia’s First Peoples.
item.dc:creator: DAMIEN CAVE

item.title: Brantley in Britain: Women Without Options and Spoiled for Choice
item.media:description: Philippa Quinn as Georgie, a woman on the cusp of 30, in a rare revival of the 1911 play “Just to Get Married.”
item.description: Plays in London spanning more than a century suggest how much and how little has changed for British women.
item.dc:creator: BEN BRANTLEY
